utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: This movie baffles me every time we watch it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What do you mean?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, the instructions are very clear, don’t feed the gremlins after midnight, don’t get the gremlins wet. How hard is that?

utterance.speaker: Penny (arriving)
utterance.content: Hi, guys. Hi, honey.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Ooh, we’re honey now, are we?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes. Since their relationship became carnal, Penny has upgraded his designated term of endearment, thus distinguishing him from those she calls sweetie, usually in an attempt to soften a thinly-veiled insult.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You’re boring people sweetie.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Although, sometimes, she omits the veil entirely.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: So, what are you guys doing?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Celebrating Columbus Day.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: We’re watching Goonies, Gremlins and Young Sherlock Holmes. They were all written by Chris Columbus.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay. What do you watch on Thanksgiving?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The parade.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, you know, that reminds me, I usually go back to Nebraska for thanksgiving, but this year they’re calling it off on account of my brother’s trial.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What’s he on trial for?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, just a big misunderstanding. You know, you’d actually like my brother, he’s kind of a chemist. Anyway, I was thinking I’d have thanksgiving here, and you are all invited.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh. I’ll be there.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Will you be serving cranberry jelly or cranberry sauce?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I guess I could serve both.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You guess? You don’t seem to have much of a handle on this.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, I really wish I could, Penny, but every year my mother has all the relatives over and cooks up her famous tur-briska-fil.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Tur-briska-fil?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Turkey stuffed with a brisket stuffed with gefilte fish. It’s not as good as it sounds.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Raj, what about you?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, he usually comes to my house. Right, pal? All right, this year, you don’t have to eat the tur-briska-fil. I don’t even chew it. I swallow it like pills.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So, what’s going on with Raj?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Well, the good news is, he has no problem with my mother’s tur-brka-fil.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hard to believe, but go on.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: The bad news is, he says he’s getting deported.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What do you mean, he’s getting deported?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I believe it means that the U.S. Government is going to expel him from the country. He could then either return to his native India, emigrate to another country that’s willing to accept him, or wander the high seas as a stateless pirate. Personally, I’d choose pirate.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Penny, would you mind stepping outside so we can speak to him?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Ugh, fine. But the man really needs to work on his girl issues.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Another reason to consider a life of piracy. Even today, I understand that’s an all-male profession.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, she’s gone.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Sorry. I lost my cool.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So, what’s going on?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Okay, here’s the deal, six months ago, my research testing the predicted composition of trans-Neptunian objects ran into a dead end.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: So?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: So, my visa’s only good as long as I’m employed at the university, and when they find out I’ve got squat, they’re going to cut me off. By the way, when I say squat, I mean diddly-squat. I wish I had squat.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So, wait, what have you been doing for the past six months?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You know, checking e-mail, updating my facebook status, messing up wikipedia entries. Hey, did you know Netflix lets you stream movies on your computer now?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: And you’ve continued to take the university’s money under false pretences? Highly unethical for an astrophysicist. Although practically mandatory for a pirate.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I don’t want to go back to India. It’s hot and loud, and there’s so many people. You have no idea, they’re everywhere.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, guys, think, how do we keep Raj in the country?

utterance.speaker: Penny (from outside)
utterance.content: Why doesn’t he just get another job?

utterance.speaker: Howard (after Raj whispers to him)
utterance.content: What are you asking me for? I don’t know if you can talk now or not.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, beef, I’m going to miss you so much. Do you know, at the Mumbai McDonald’s, you can’t get a Big Mac? All you can get is a Chicken Maharaja Mac. And the special sauce, curry, which, in India,

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Don’t worry, you’ll find another job.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Yeah let me start practicing for it. Do you want fries with that Maharaja Mac?”

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hi, Leonard. Hello, Raj.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hello Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Forgive me, as you know, I’m no adept at reading facial cues, but I’m going to take a stab here, you’re either sad or nauseated.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m sad.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I was going to say sad. I don’t know why I hedged.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What are you eating?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Elbow macaroni with ground hamburger and tomato sauce.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, beefaroni. I think I’ll miss you most of all.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’ve always been a little confused about this. Why don’t Hindus eat beef?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: We believe cows are gods.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Not technically. In Hinduism, cattle are thought to be like God.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Do not tell me about my own culture, Sheldon! In the mood I’m in, I’ll take you out, I swear to cow!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Me, too. I’m just, I’m a little on edge.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Understandable. Your entire life seems to be crumbling around you, and your future appears bleak at best.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: And you’re wrong about Hinduism and cows.

utterance.speaker: Howard (arriving)
utterance.content: Hey, Raj, guess what. Professor Laughlin is looking for someone to join the stellar evolution research team.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You, you’re kidding. That’s fantastic!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Come on, what are you waiting for? Call him and set up an interview.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m on it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s happy, right?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Nailed it.

utterance.speaker: Prof Laughlin
utterance.content: Dr. Koothrappali, come on in. I was surprised to hear you were interested In joining our little team. Giving up on those trans-Neptunian objects, are we?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: No, no, it’s a very promising area. In a perfect world I’d spend several more years on it. But I just couldn’t pass up the opportunity to work with you on your tremendously exciting and not yet conclusively disproved hypothesis.

utterance.speaker: Prof Laughlin
utterance.content: Splendid. Uh, please sit down. Can I offer you a sherry?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: It’s a little early, isn’t it?

utterance.speaker: Prof Laughlin
utterance.content: Not on Proxima Centauri.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: That’s very good. Jolly amusing, but if you don’t mind, I’ll hold off until sunset on titan.

utterance.speaker: Prof Laughlin
utterance.content: Oh, well done. I have a feeling you’re going to fit in just fine, Dr. Koothrappali.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Thank you, sir.

utterance.speaker: Woman
utterance.content: I’m sorry. Am I late?

utterance.speaker: Prof Laughlin
utterance.content: No, no, no. Right on time. Dr. Koothrappali, may I present Dr. Millstone from MIT. She’ll be heading up our data analysis team.

utterance.speaker: Dr Millstone
utterance.content: It’s nice to meet you, Dr. Koothrappali. I read your paper on Kuiper belt object size distribution. I really enjoyed it. How did you correct for the selection bias?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Well, I ran a simulation that allowed me to correct for the observational efficiency.

utterance.speaker: Dr Millstone
utterance.content: That’s just fascinating.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Thank you. Would you like to hear more about it in my hot tub? So, when do I start?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What do you mean you didn’t get the job? How could you not get it?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You know, he’s British, I’m Indian, ever since Gandhi they haven’t liked us very much.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Wait, are you saying that he discriminated against you? Because we should file a complaint.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: That’s okay. A complaint has been filed. So, that’s it. That was my last hope. I’m going to be deported, sent home in disgrace, exposed to the sardonic barbs of my cousin Sanjay. Or, as you may know him, Dave from AT_T customer service.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I’m really going to miss you.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Will you come visit me in India?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Gee, that’s, like, a 17-hour flight. How about I meet you halfway?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Halfway is 600 miles off the coast of Japan.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Tell you what, we’ll skype.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (arriving)
utterance.content: Gentlemen.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Raj, did you get the job with Professor Laughlin?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I assumed as much. But never fear. Like the subordinate male protagonist in countless action movies who disappears half way through the second reel, I have returned to save the day. Odd, usually, he’s met by cheers. Anyway, I was thinking about exploring the string theory implications of gamma rays from dark matter annihilations, and it occurred to me that I could benefit…

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Excuse me, Sheldon, how many reels before the subordinate male protagonist gets to his point?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m sorry, if you didn’t cheer at my entrance, it’s too late to buy into the premise. Anyway, I got some extra money from the head of the department, and raj can come work for me.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You want me to work with you?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: For me. You’re going to have to listen more carefully when you’re on the job.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Okay, uh, please don’t take this the wrong way, but I’d rather swim buck-naked across the Ganges with a paper cut on my nipple and die a slow, agonizing death from a viral infection than work with you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: For me.

utterance.speaker: Raj (knocking and entering)
utterance.content: Sheldon, are you busy?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Of course I’m busy.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Shall I wait?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes, please. How may I help you?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’ve reconsidered your offer to let me work with you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: For me.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Yes, for you. I do, however, have a few conditions. First, at all times, I am to be treated as a colleague and an equal. Second, my contributions shall be noted in all published material. And third, you are never allowed to lecture me on Hinduism or my Indian culture.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m impressed, Raj. Those are very cogent and reasonable conditions.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I reject them all.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Then you leave me no choice. I accept the job.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m sorry, I believe you’ve misunderstood. I’m not giving you the job. I’m simply affording you the opportunity to apply for it. Have a seat, we’ll get started with the interview.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Wha… You’re kidding!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Please.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: All right.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: So, that’s what you wear to an interview?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Come on, dude, we’ve been friends for years.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, pulling strings, are we?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Sheldon, for God’s sakes, don’t make me beg.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Bazinga! You’ve fallen victim to another one of my classic practical jokes. I’m your boss now. You may want to laugh at that.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Ah, it’s nice having the place to ourselves, isn’t it?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Uh-huh. Now that Raj is working for Sheldon, I don’t have to chauffeur him around anymore. Plus, yeah, with them working late so much, we get some privacy.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Mm-hmm. Hey, want to get a little crazy?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What are you thinking?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Let’s slide over to Sheldon’s spot a make out.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You are a dirty girl.

utterance.speaker: Penny (as the making out is interrupted by a knock on the door)
utterance.content: Oh, God, how did he know?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hello.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hi, Howard.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Am I interrupting?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Little bit, yeah.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Guess I should have called.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, maybe.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Tonight’s the night I usually go line dancing with Raj at the palomino.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Uh-huh.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: But he’s working with Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yes, we know.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Want me to leave?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You know, whatever.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, I guess I can hang for a little while. So what are we watching? Sex and the city.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey, I happen to love this movie.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Fine, let’s watch it. Maybe all our periods will synchronize.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right, we’re going to be designing an experiment to look for the annihilation spectrum resulting from dark matter collisions in space.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Ooh, dark matter. We better bring a flashlight. I was making a joke.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m the boss. I make the jokes.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Sorry, go ahead and make your joke.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: This is not the time for joking. We’re doing serious research, which requires complete and utter focus.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: All right, let’s buckle down and work.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I need an aspirin.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Top desk drawer.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Alright?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Good.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That was fun. Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Leonard, honey, you don’t have to say thank you every time we have sex.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh. Okay. Tomorrow you’re going to get a card in the mail. Just throw it away.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Top o’ the mornin’o ya!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What are you doing here?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Well, usually, on Sundays, I go with Raj to scam on hippie chicks at the farmers market, but he’s still working with Sheldon, so I thought I’d come over here and make you guys scrambled eggs and salami. It’s the perfect meal for apres l’amour.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, kill me.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: By the way, I couldn’t help overhearing your big finish. Bravo, Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: See, if you had killed me when I said kill me, I wouldn’t have had to hear that.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What do you guys think? Want to take in a matinee, maybe go rollerblading, catch a step class?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Do something.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, okay. Um, Howard, we need to talk.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sure. ‘sup, homes?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Uh, please understand that it’s not that we don’t want you around, but Penny and I occasionally need some alone time.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh. I get it, I’m the third wheel. Sorry, I should have seen that. I’ll get out of your way. Uh, you’re gonna want to eat those eggs while they’re still hot.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Thank you. There’s lox and cream cheese in the fridge, the bagels are in the oven, I was warming them up.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: That’s great.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Ill just hang out with my mom. That’s always fun.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Good.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Are we terrible people?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I don’t know. What do you want me to do?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Get him, bring him back.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Are you sure?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay. Howard come back.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, you guys had me scared for a minute.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: No, no, no, no! That rate is much too low for what we’d expect from this collision. Do you understand that we’re talking about dark matter colliding in outer space?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Of course I understand. And who are you to tell me about outer space?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m the astrophysicist. Astro means space.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Astro means star.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Okay, well, let me just tell you, if we were having this argument in my native language, I’d be kicking your butt.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: English is your native language.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Okay, you got me there, but you’re wrong about this!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: There is a fine line between wrong and visionary. Unfortunately you have to be a visionary to see it.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: My god, you think that every thought that comes out of your head is pure gold. Well, let me tell you something. Some of those thoughts are pure caca.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Caca?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: It means doo-doo.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right! First of all, Dr. Koothrappali, when I first proposed that you work with me…

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Aha! So I am working with you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: In this context, with me means for me.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Ah, well, in this context…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh! If I’m wrong, prove it.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Okay. Here’s where we derive the mass of the dark matter particle.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, no, no, you’ve misstated the atomic weight of the target.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Let me finish.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’re defacing my work.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m not defacing it, I’m fixing it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Give me the eraser.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I said give it to me.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Come and get it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Fine. Oh, lord. Dr. Koothrappali, as your superior, I forbid you from writing on my board!

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You are not my superior.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I am in every way.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, yeah? Can you do this? Nice working with you. I’m sorry, for you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Raj. Raj. Raj.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m busy.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Doing what? All right, you’ve made your point.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What do you want, Sheldon?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I looked over the board and it turns out you were right.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: So you were wrong.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I didn’t say that.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: That’s the only logical inference.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Nevertheless, I didn’t say it. Anyway, I would like you to come back and work for me.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: For you or with you?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: In this context for me could mean with me.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: All right, but I have some conditions.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I reject them all.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’ll take the job. See you Monday.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Wait, you have to drive me home.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: How did you get here?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I walked.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: So walk home.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I can’t. There’s a big dog outside. On the way home, we can start thinking about methods of optimizing the detector for 500 GEV particles.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: All right.
